counter.name: Calls - Parses
counter.desc: Number of parses runs. This number should be reduced by application tuning if possible.

counter.name: Calls - Reads / User calls
counter.desc: Ratio of reads to user calls in Oracle7.

counter.name: Calls - Recursive calls
counter.desc: Number of recursive database calls. A high value indicates the information was frequently not found in the dictionary buffer. The dictionary buffer may be sized too small or has been parsed too many times.

counter.name: Calls - User calls
counter.desc: The number of user calls started for the database.

counter.name: Calls - User/Recursive calls
counter.desc: Ratio of user to recursive calls in Oracle7 monitor.

counter.name: Calls - commits
counter.desc: The number of commits carried out (finished transactions).

counter.name: Calls - rollbacks
counter.desc: The number of the executed rollbacks (rolling back incomplete transactions).

counter.name: Data buffer - Buffer busy waits
counter.id: Database Performance/Data buffer - Buffer busy waits
counter.desc: No Description

counter.name: Data buffer - Buffer wait time s
counter.id: Database Performance/Data buffer - Buffer wait time s
counter.desc: No Description

counter.name: Data buffer - Physical reads
counter.desc: Number of database blocks read physically from the hard disk.

counter.name: Data buffer - Quality %
counter.desc: The quality specifies how high the percentage of the reads without hard disk accesses from the total quantity of read accesses to the database buffer pool is.

counter.name: Data buffer - Reads
counter.desc: The number of read accesses which could be satisfied directly (without hard disk access) from the database buffer pool.

counter.name: Data buffer - Size kb
counter.desc: The size of the databse pool,which holds the database blocks in the working storage and therefore, reduces time-consuming hard disk accesses.

counter.name: Data buffer - writes
counter.desc: No Description

counter.name: Log buffer - Alloc fault rate %
counter.id: Database Performance/Log buffer - Alloc fault rate %
counter.desc: The percentage of aborted allocation attempts (allocation fault) from the total quantity of entries in the redo log buffer (entries).

counter.name: Log buffer - Allocation retries
counter.desc: Frequency, with which a user process could not allocate sufficient space in the redo log buffer and had to start a further attempt. This case can then occur if the redo writer is working less efficiently or if an event occurs such as a log switch.

counter.name: Log buffer - Entries
counter.desc: The number of entries in the redo log buffer.

counter.name: Log buffer - Log files (in use)
counter.id: Database Performance/Log buffer - Log files (in use)
counter.desc: Number of redo log files.

counter.name: Log buffer - Redo log wait s
counter.id: Database Performance/Log buffer - Redo log wait s
counter.desc: Redo log space wait time (s) from v$sysstat

counter.name: Log buffer - Size kb
counter.desc: Size of the redo log buffer in KB.In the redo log buffer, all changes to the database are logged.

counter.name: Redo logging - Latching time s
counter.id: Database Performance/Redo logging - Latching time s
counter.desc: The time which the logwriter process needed to recieve and release the necessary latches (short-term locks of data structures) to the redo log.

counter.name: Redo logging - Mb written
counter.desc: The number of MB which were written to the redo log file.

counter.name: Redo logging - OS-Blocks written
counter.desc: number of blocks which were written into the redo log file.

counter.name: Redo logging - Write time s
counter.id: Database Performance/Redo logging - Write time s
counter.desc: The time in milliseconds which was needed for writing to the redo log file.

counter.name: Redo logging - Writes
counter.desc: the number of write operations which were executed on the redo log file. A database background process, the logwriter, cyclically transfers the contents of the redo log buffer into the redo log file.

counter.name: Shared Pool - DD-Cache quality %
counter.desc: Quality of the data dictionary cache in Oracle7.This value specifies how frequently the Oracle data dictionary has to be accessed when processing SQL commands. In the installed system, this value should at least be 90%.

counter.name: Shared Pool - SQL Area getratio %
counter.id: Database Performance/Shared Pool - SQL Area getratio %
counter.desc: Hit rate for the number of requests of objects which are managed in the library cache of Oracle7. A high value suggests a good sizing of the shared pool.

counter.name: Shared Pool - Size kb
counter.desc: Size of the dictionary buffer in KB.The dictionary buffer has the function to store data dictionary information which is frequently required in the working storage which facilitates the acess.

counter.name: Shared Pool - pinratio %
counter.desc: Hit rate for the number of executions of objects which are managed in the library cache of Oracle7. A high value suggests a good sizing of the shared pool.

counter.name: Shared Pool - reloads/pins %
counter.desc: SQL area reloads (%) from v$librarycache

counter.name: Sorts - Disk
counter.desc: The number of sorting operations which were carried out on the hard disk in the temporary segments provided for this. This is necessary if sorting operations cannot be handled completely in memory.

counter.name: Sorts - Memory
counter.desc: The number of sorting operations which could be carried out in memory.

counter.name: Sorts - Rows sorted
counter.desc: Number of lines which were sorted.

counter.name: Table scans & fetches - Fetch by rowid
counter.id: Database Performance/Table scans & fetches - Fetch by rowid
counter.desc: The number of blocks which were read via ROWID. the ROWID is a logical byte address which identifies every data record in the database and links it with the index value.

counter.name: Table scans & fetches - Long table scans
counter.id: Database Performance/Table scans & fetches - Long table scans
counter.desc: Number of read access to tables with at least 4 database blocks.

counter.name: Table scans & fetches - Short table scans
counter.id: Database Performance/Table scans & fetches - Short table scans
counter.desc: Number of read access to tables with a maximum size of 4 database blocks.

counter.name: Table scans & fetches - by continued row
counter.id: Database Performance/Table scans & fetches - by continued row
counter.desc: Number of accesses to concatenated database blocks (row chaining).The number should be as low as possible, otherwise, the affected tables should be reorganized.

counter.name: Time statistics - Busy wait time s
counter.id: Database Performance/Time statistics - Busy wait time s
counter.desc: Oracle: Busy wait time (from v$System_Event) (sec).

counter.name: Time statistics - CPU count
counter.desc: Number of CPUs.

counter.name: Time statistics - CPU time s
counter.id: Database Performance/Time statistics - CPU time s
counter.desc: Oracle: Total CPU time used by Oracle (sec).

counter.name: Time statistics - CPU usage %
counter.desc: Oracle: CPU usage by Oracle (%).

counter.name: Time statistics - Sessions busy %
counter.desc: Oracle: Sessions busy (%).

counter.name: Time statistics - Time/User call ms
counter.id: Database Performance/Time statistics - Time/User call ms
counter.desc: Oracle: Time per user call (ms).

counter.name: CPU Time
counter.desc: CPU Time consumed

counter.name: Dialog steps
counter.desc: Dialog steps

counter.name: Average CPU time
counter.desc: Average CPU time used in the work process. During a dialog step, the CPU of the application server is used for processing (loading, generating, database request processing, ABAP processing and so on). The CPU time is determined by the operating system. At the end of a transaction step, the R/3 work process queries the CPU time from the operating system. The CPU time is therefore not an additive component of the response time, unlike the wait, roll-in, load and database time.

counter.name: Av. RFC+CPIC time
counter.desc: Average RFC & CPIC time

counter.name: Av. response time
counter.desc: The average response time of a dialog step is the average time measured from the time a dialog sends a request to the dispatcher work process through the processing of the dialog up to the time the dialog is completed and the data is passed to the presentation layer. The response time between the SAP GUI and the dispatcher is not included in this value. The response time does NOT include the time taken to transfer data from the R/3 frontend to the application server. For networks with low performance, this can create a highly subjective response time. The transfer time is contained in the GUI network time. Response time is usually split into wait time plus dispatch time. The CPU time is not an additive component of the response time, but the sum of the CPU time that is used by the individual components. The CPU time therefore provides additional, independent information on the response time.

counter.name: Average wait time
counter.desc: The time an unprocessed dialog step waits in the dispatcher queue for a free work process. Under normal conditions, the dispatcher work process should pass a dialog step to the application process immediately after receiving the request from the dialog step. Under these conditions, the average wait time would be a few milliseconds. A heavy load on the application server or on the entire system causes queues at the dispatcher queue.

counter.name: Average load time
counter.desc: The time needed to load and generate objects such as ABAP source code and screen information from the database.

counter.name: Av. Roll i+w time
counter.desc: Average Roll i+w time

counter.name: Av. DB req. time
counter.desc: Average Database request time

counter.name: Av. enqueue time
counter.desc: Average enqueue time

counter.name: Average bytes req.
counter.desc: Average bytes per requests

counter.name: Database calls
counter.desc: The number of parsed requests sent to the database

counter.name: Database requests
counter.desc: The number of logical ABAP requests for data in the database. These requests are passed through the R/3 database interface and parsed into individual database calls. The proportion of database calls to database requests is important. If access to information in a table is buffered in the SAP buffers, database calls to the database server are not required. Therefore, the ratio of calls/requests gives an overall indication of the efficiency of table buffering. A good ratio would be 1:10.

counter.name: DB Calls: Direct reads
counter.desc: Database Calls: Direct reads

counter.name: DB Calls: Sequential reads
counter.desc: Database Calls: Sequential reads

counter.name: DB Calls: Changes
counter.desc: Database Calls: Changes

counter.name: Time per DB request
counter.desc: Average response time for all commands sent to the database system (in milliseconds). The time depends on the CPU capacity of the database server, network, buffering, and on the input/output capabilities of the database server. Access times for buffered tables are many magnitudes faster and are not considered in the measurement.

counter.name: Time per Req.: Direct reads
counter.desc: Time per Database request.: Direct reads

counter.name: Time per Req.: Sequential reads
counter.desc: Time per Database request.: Sequential reads

counter.name: Time per Req.: Changes and commits
counter.id: Workload/Time per Req.: Changes and commits
counter.desc: Time per Database request.: Changes and commits

counter.name: Roll-in time
counter.desc: Processing time for roll ins.

counter.name: Roll-out time
counter.desc: Processing time for roll outs.

counter.name: Roll wait time
counter.desc: Queue time in the roll area. When synchronous RFCs are called, the work process executes a roll out and may have to wait for the end of the RFC in the roll area, even if the dialog step is not yet completed. In the roll area, RFC server programs can also wait for other RFCs sent to them.

counter.name: Roll-ins
counter.desc: Number of rolled-in user contexts.

counter.name: Roll-outs
counter.desc: Number of rolled-out user contexts.
